paragraphs.text: I think there are also a lot of interesting things to explore with multi-agent as a form of test-time compute. Letting many Claudes work on a problem can yield a better final answer than just one.
Hi, I'm Alex. I lead Claude Relations here at Anthropic. Today, we're going to be talking about building more effective agents, and I'm joined by my colleague.
I'm Eric. I work on multi-agent research here at Anthropic.
Eric, to kick us off here, can you explain why Claude is so good at agent tasks?

Yes, sure. During our training, we let Claude practice being an agent. We give it open-ended problems to work on where it can take many steps, use tools, and explore what it's working on before giving a final answer. By getting a lot of practice being an agent, Claude becomes really good at this.
Okay, so it's these long-running tasks in a variety of domains. Through the process of RL and other training mechanisms, Claude is learning how to do these things with limited guidance or feedback.
Exactly. We do a lot of RL on coding tasks, search tasks, and many other things for Claude to practice being an agent in different environments.
There's a conception that Claude models are very strong in code, but that it doesn't always transfer to other domains, or that coding is its own separate thing. What are your views on that generally?

Coding has been the first task we've really focused on. Once you have an amazing coding agent, that agent can do any other kind of work. If you need to do a search, you can do web search via APIs. You can plan a weekend by creating a schedule.

We really see coding as a very fundamental skill for an agent that will have a lot of spillover effect, making Claude great at all sorts of things. It's like training on the hardest thing first, and then everything else becomes easy.

One interesting thing I've seen recently with a feature we released in Cloud.ai on the web was the ability for Claude to create actual files through writing code. It was like writing a Python script, and then the Python script ran. All of a sudden, an Excel sheet popped out of that.
Is that the future direction we're headed? Is Claude writing scripts and taking actions on computers to create files or do things that are traditionally not code-related?

I think that's one of the really effective ways Claude will be able to do these things. Just a few days ago, Claude was helping me make some diagrams for a presentation. It was able to create files just by writing out the SVGs.

But then I wanted it to make a much more detailed diagram that would need a lot of repetition. So Claude was able to do this by writing some code to generate the SVG, which ran much faster than Claude itself needing to write it. It was a very repetitive image file with lots of detailed patterns.
I think for a lot of cases, writing code to produce an artifact will be much better than trying to create that artifact directly. It's one way to do it for harder cases.
Code allows for a speed up that's not even possible with a human clicking, dragging, and using their mouse on a computer for repeated actions. Exactly. Claude gets a for loop.

If you're a developer and building an agent with Claude, one thing we've started to see become really popular is the Claude Code SDK. Can you walk me through what that is and how you're seeing developers starting to use that?

We're really excited about developers using the Claude Code SDK. Previously, if you wanted to build a coding agent or any agent, you had to go from nothing but hitting an API endpoint. You had to build the loops yourself, build all the tools, execute these tools, and interact with files or MCP.
We have already built all of that into Cloud Code. Even though its name is Cloud Code, it is a general-purpose agent most often used for code.

We are encouraging many developers to use this SDK as the core of their agent loop. That way, they do not have to spend a lot of time reinventing the wheel; we have already invested considerable time into polishing and perfecting that core agent loop. Instead, they can use it and simply add their tools for their own custom business logic or affordances via MCP.
It offers customizability, allowing you to remove the coding-specific bits and insert whatever prompts or tools you need. It slots nicely into the scaffold.

People have been using Cloud Code for all sorts of things. My strangest use of Cloud Code was having it plan a date for me, where it performed web searches to find interesting activities and restaurants in the area. It was not code-related at all, but it has all the necessary tools.
How was the date?
It was pretty good. It was great; Cloud did a good job.
Filoli Gardens and then a Chinese restaurant nearby. Wow, okay. Cloud did a good job. I am impressed.

Another popular feature of Cloud Code that I have seen many software engineers use lately is Cloud MD files. These are files you define within a project that give Cloud relevant information about your programming style or the layout of directories, among other things.
We have now launched a similar concept that takes a step further, called Skills. Can you explain what Skills are, how developers are using them, and what they mean for agents?

Cloud Skills are an exciting extension of Cloud MD files. Instead of just giving them note files, you can give them any type of file. These can include PowerPoint template files, code and helper scripts, or images and assets.

This extension provides not just instructions but also resources for the agent to use, which is a powerful tool. For example, you might say, "These are my instructions for making PowerPoint presentations," and also provide the headshots of all company leadership that might be reused in many presentations. This gives Claude everything it needs in a reusable way.

One analogy I've heard used internally that I really liked is from The Matrix, when Neo learns Kung Fu for the first time. They inject him with the information, and suddenly he's a Kung Fu master. It feels very similar to giving Claude a skill. For instance, you provide instructions on how to create spreadsheets, and suddenly Claude acts like a banker, creating a financial model. It's like loading in all the racks of equipment and tools for them to grab. You can start with these things, not just instructions.

Switching gears a little, the last time we chatted on camera a few months back, we were talking about agents. At the time, we were transitioning from workflows, which are very defined ways of chaining prompts together, to a single agent system where you run a model in a loop. What has been the evolution in this space since then?

Weve really seen agents take over from workflows. Claude has become so good at responding to feedback and correcting its own work that agent loops now dramatically outperform workflows for most things where absolute quality is a priority.
They are still great where you need very low latency, and you want Claude to just give a best answer in a single shot. Agents are really high performance now.

One of the things I've seen develop since then is what I call "workflows of agents." Previously, an application might have had a workflow that used Claude in a single shot to write a SQL command to load data. That would then go to another step in the workflow where it would write a chart to display that data. If the SQL command failed, it wouldn't know it wasn't returning any data, and the second step of the workflow would be completely incorrect.

But now, I've seen people where each one of those steps in the workflow is actually a closed loop. Instead of just writing a single attempt at a SQL query, it runs, Claude sees the output, and then it can keep iterating and repeating until it knows it got the right value. Then, it transitions to the next step in the workflow.
Okay, interesting. So, this is an evolution of chaining together prompts to now chaining together agents in these loops themselves. We'll see where that goes from there.

One other big topic of discussion that has garnered more chatter as of late is this question around observability and verification. Can you explain what that challenge is and how people are starting to think about it?

Observability is very hard for agents, especially as the systems get more complex. I still really believe that even though the models are much more capable today than they were a year ago and can work better in an agent or even more complex setups, simplicity is still a really important thing. Even though you can build a big workflow of agents, you should still start from the simplest possible thing and then work up to a more complex solution.

First, try single-shotting things or using a single-shot prompt to the Cloud Code SDK, which is now such a simple, easy thing to use. Then, only as needed, add layers of complexity, because that will make absorbability harder.
Another term, perhaps in parallel to workflows of agents, is multi-agent. Is that the same thing, or is it something different?
Multi-agent is my main area of research now. I'd say it's pretty different from a workflow of an agent.
Workflows of agents involve one agent that goes, finishes, and then transitions, or its output gets sent to the next agent to work on.

Multi-agent is where fundamentally you have multiple agents or multiple Clouds working at the same time. One parent agent might delegate tasks to five sub-agents that can each work in parallel. This is how our deep research search product works.

The main orchestrator agent decides and creates several sub-agents that can do many searches in parallel. That's much better for the user because all this happens in parallel, and you get the answer back much sooner.

We also see that in Cloud Code, the model uses a sub-agent. If a subtask is going to take tens of thousands of tokensfor example, finding a certain implementation of a classbut the answer really boils down to something very small, it can do that work in a sub-agent. This protects the main context from all those tokens that aren't necessary for the main work.
It can offload this piece of work and just get back the final answer it needs.
Are we exposing this sub-agent, in this case, as a tool that Cloud can call upon?
Exactly. It will pass in the prompt as a parameter or something.
Exactly. To Cloud, sub-agents look like a tool where it can pass prompts to the sub-agents that will then go and do work.
Part of my research is training Cloud to be a better manager and to give clear instructions to its sub-agents, ensuring it gets the right things it needs from them.

How is this different, or is it a specialized part of tool calling? Or is it different in some ways? I would say this uses the framework of tool calling for that communication protocol. It just happens to be a tool that is itself backed by another Claude.

Does Claude have an intuitive understanding of what a sub-agent is, or do we have to teach it? For example, "You're actually talking to another version of yourself, Claude; don't get freaked out." I would say that Claude makes a lot of the same mistakes that first-time managers make. It will give incomplete or unclear instructions to a sub-agent and expect the sub-agent to have the right context when it actually doesn't.

Something we've seen during training on sub-agents is that Claude starts to get much more verbose and detailed, giving its sub-agents the overall context of what's going on so they can do better work that adds up to the whole. So, Claude definitely has a lot to learn and is learning to get better at this.
Okay, cool. What are some of the use cases here? Search is one, and preserving context. Are there other things that people are using multi-agent for right now?

Yes, there's a lot of sub-agent use in coding. Anything that can be parallelized or map-reduced, if you have something where you need to produce a lot of output, or there are maybe ten parts of some output you're creating, if you can split that up among ten sub-agents, that can be really, really effective for saving context and getting faster results.

I think there are also a lot of interesting things to explore with multi-agent as a form of test-time compute. Letting many Claudes work on a problem can get you a better final answer than just one, just like a group of people putting their heads together can get better results.
In that case, are we specializing these agents in any way? Do we gear them towards one type of persona or another? Or do we just let them take whatever form?

I think you can do either. Sometimes it's helpful to give a bunch of people the same exact task and see what the different answers they come up with are. Sometimes it's good to have many people or many agents work from different approaches to the same problem or split it up.
One thing I've seen a lot is customers who have many tools, maybe 100 or 200, that they want an agent to use. They found it's really good to split up those tools among subagents.

The main agent only needs to know, "I want to use this bucket of tools." Then, a subagent goes and does the actual work. Each subagent then only has maybe 20 tools that it needs to understand and know how to use.
Have we tried scaling agents all the way up? What happens if you have a thousand versions of Claude all working on one problem? Does it just turn into chaos?
I've not tried that yet, but I'll get back to you. That's a good research idea.
What are some other failure modes that we're seeing right now with agents or multi-agents?
I think, just like any complex system, it's easy to overbuild something and lose a lot of efficiency, creating a lot of dead weight.
I've seen overbuilt multi-agent systems spend too much time talking back and forth with each other and not making progress on the main task.
Human organizations suffer from this too. As companies get bigger, they have more communication overhead, and less work is done by the people on the ground making progress on things.
That's another interesting thing to study: how can we make organizations of Claudes very effective while keeping the overhead small?
If I'm a developer wanting to get started with agents, whether building on the Claude Code SDK or just trying to roll my own, do you have any tips or best practices you'd give them?
The best practice is to start simply and only add complexities as needed. Another important thing is to think from the point of view of your agents.

If you are giving Claude tools, prompts, or any affordances, put yourself in Claude's shoes. Read what it actually receives as the model and ensure there is enough information for it to solve the problem. It is easy to forget that we see everything, but the model only sees what we show it.

It's always important to review the raw transcript of your tool calls and logs. As people build more multi-component prompts (MCPs) and connect Claude to more things, a natural but incorrect first instinct is that an MCP or tools should be one-to-one with your API.
Instead, tools for the model or MCPs should be one-to-one with your user interface (UI), not your API. The model is a user of these things; it does not work like a traditional program.

For example, if your API has three separate endpoints for loading a Slack conversation, turning a user ID into a username, and turning a channel ID into a channel name, and those are the tools you give the model to understand Slack, it will have to make three tool calls to understand anything.

As a user, we see everything nicely rendered. Therefore, you want to create a tool or an MCP for the model that presents everything at once with as little interaction as possible. It would be terrible for a user if, every time they used Slack, they had to click on a user ID to see the name.
It's about working back from the desired end state instead of simply mapping technical specifications one-to-one, and surrounding it with whatever context you need.
What do you think the future of agents has in store for us? Any predictions for the next six to 12 months?
I think agents are going to become a lot more pervasive, starting in areas that are verifiable, like software engineering.
Coding agents have already changed how I work and how tons of people at Anthropic work. I think there's still a huge amount to be gained there.
One of the really exciting things is if agents can start getting better at verifying their own work with computer use.

They can write a web app, but can they actually open it up, test it, and find their own bugs instead of you needing to do that? Closing that loop of testing is one of the most exciting things, so I don't have to be Claude's QA engineer.
So, combining software engineering abilities with computer use abilities, once we put all these pieces together.
Yes, I think computer use is also going to really open up a lot of other avenues and domains where agents have been locked out of so far.
What would be an example of that?
If you want Claude to do work for you in a Google Doc, right now Claude can write for you, but you're copying and pasting back and forth.
But if you have computer use and you say, "Hey, Claude, can you clean up this Google Doc?" it can do it right there for you, scrolling around, clicking, and editing the text.
That's such a nicer experience than needing to copy and paste back and forth.
Yes, it's like wherever you are, Claude can be there with you through computer use.
Oh, I'm very excited to have Claude write my Google Docs and respond to all of my comments for me.
Exactly. That would be a very nice future.
Eric, this has been great. Thank you so much for the conversation.
Absolutely. Thank you.
